articles.headline: Stay or Go? Biden, Long a Critic of Afghan Deployments, Faces a Deadline
articles.snippet: The question is whether the small contingent of American troops can accomplish anything after 20 years — and whether full withdrawal would clear the way for Taliban advances.
articles.abstract: The question is whether the small contingent of American troops can accomplish anything after 20 years — and whether full withdrawal would clear the way for Taliban advances.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The previous two presidents of the United States declared they wanted to pull all American troops out of Afghanistan, and they both decided in the end that they could not do it.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: On Trump, Michigan Republicans Lean One Way: ‘Fealty at All Costs’
articles.snippet: Even after his defeat, Donald Trump is causing fierce infighting among Republicans in a crucial battleground state. Loyalists are rewarded. Dissenters face punishment.
articles.abstract: Even after his defeat, Donald Trump is causing fierce infighting among Republicans in a crucial battleground state. Loyalists are rewarded. Dissenters face punishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROCKFORD, Mich. — When Representative Peter Meijer voted to impeach Donald J. Trump in January, making him one of 10 House Republicans who bucked their party, he bluntly acknowledged that “it may have been an act of political suicide.”

articles.headline: Winter Storm Disrupts Wide Swath of American Business
articles.snippet: Power outages, natural gas shortages and icy conditions made it hard for automakers, retailers and delivery carriers to operate across much of the South and Midwest.
articles.abstract: Power outages, natural gas shortages and icy conditions made it hard for automakers, retailers and delivery carriers to operate across much of the South and Midwest.
articles.lead_paragraph: The winter storm that barreled across much of the United States over the holiday weekend severely disrupted businesses including large car factories, retail chains and the delivery services that people are deeply reliant on for basic necessities.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: Through Chattering Teeth, Texans Criticize Extended Power Outages
articles.snippet: “I’m kind of angry,” said one man whose family has been without power since Monday. A winter storm caused physical damage to the electrical grid’s infrastructure as well as a surge in demand.
articles.abstract: “I’m kind of angry,” said one man whose family has been without power since Monday. A winter storm caused physical damage to the electrical grid’s infrastructure as well as a surge in demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — Texans shivered under blankets as their electricity flickered off and temperatures inside their homes plummeted. Some awoke on Tuesday to find icicles had formed from dripping kitchen faucets. And in a Houston suburb, a woman and her three grandchildren who had been relying on a fireplace for heat were killed after the authorities said a blaze engulfed their home.
articles.byline: By David Montgomery, Rick Rojas, Ivan Penn and James Dobbins

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Reaches a Deal to Buy Tribune Publishing
articles.snippet: Alden Global Capital’s move continues the financial industry’s acquisition of major newspaper chains. The Baltimore Sun, a Tribune paper, will be sold to a Maryland hotel executive.
articles.abstract: Alden Global Capital’s move continues the financial industry’s acquisition of major newspaper chains. The Baltimore Sun, a Tribune paper, will be sold to a Maryland hotel executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: In another sign of the financial industry’s increasing influence on the newspaper business, Tribune Publishing, the publisher of nine major metropolitan dailies including The Chicago Tribune and The Daily News, announced on Tuesday that it had agreed to give complete ownership of the company to Alden Global Capital, a hedge fund that has drastically cut costs at newspapers it controls.

articles.headline: ‘How Many Funerals Will Come Out of This One?’
articles.snippet: Suspicious of secular authority, Israel’s ultra-Orthodox Jews have often flouted antivirus protocols. Wary of hospitals, many prefer to stay home when they do get sick. A look inside an insular culture that has been both a vector for the virus and...
articles.abstract: Suspicious of secular authority, Israel’s ultra-Orthodox Jews have often flouted antivirus protocols. Wary of hospitals, many prefer to stay home when they do get sick. A look inside an insular culture that has been both a vector for the virus and its victim.
articles.lead_paragraph: Suspicious of secular authority, Israel’s ultra-Orthodox Jews have often flouted antivirus protocols. Wary of hospitals, many prefer to stay home when they do get sick. A look inside an insular culture that has been both a vector for the virus and its victim.
articles.byline: By Dan Balilty and Patrick Kingsley

articles.headline: Oregon Is Vaccinating Teachers. It Might Not Be Enough to Reopen Schools.
articles.snippet: Oregon is a case study in how Pacific Coast cities are lagging the country in resuming in-person teaching.
articles.abstract: Oregon is a case study in how Pacific Coast cities are lagging the country in resuming in-person teaching.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly before Christmas, as Oregon schools faced their 10th month under some of the nation’s sternest coronavirus restrictions, Gov. Kate Brown began a major push to reopen classrooms.

articles.headline: This Cloud Computing Billing Expert Is Very Funny. Seriously.
articles.snippet: Corey Quinn has made it his business to understand Amazon’s cloud-computing charges and have some fun at the company’s expense.
articles.abstract: Corey Quinn has made it his business to understand Amazon’s cloud-computing charges and have some fun at the company’s expense.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — When Jeff Barr, a prominent executive at Amazon’s cloud computing division and a prodigious corporate blogger, celebrated his 60th birthday last year, Corey Quinn had a surprise for him: a music video that mocked Amazon’s business.

articles.headline: How to Buy a Real N95 Mask Online
articles.snippet: Fakes and little-known brands still abound, even as health officials have advised us to up our mask game. Here’s what to do.
articles.abstract: Fakes and little-known brands still abound, even as health officials have advised us to up our mask game. Here’s what to do.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Europe’s Pandemic Debt Is Dizzying. Who Will Pay?
articles.snippet: Pandemic aid has cushioned workers and businesses from a severe recession. But as governments face trillions in debt, there’s no rush to rein it in.
articles.abstract: Pandemic aid has cushioned workers and businesses from a severe recession. But as governments face trillions in debt, there’s no rush to rein it in.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — For nearly six months, Philippe Boreal and 120 of his fellow workers have been paid to stay home from their jobs at a Cannes luxury hotel that was forced to close for the pandemic.

articles.headline: Facebook Blocks News in Australia, Diverging With Google on Proposed Law
articles.snippet: With Australia moving to make the tech companies pay for news, Facebook took a hard line, while Google has struck deals to pay publishers.
articles.abstract: With Australia moving to make the tech companies pay for news, Facebook took a hard line, while Google has struck deals to pay publishers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For months, Facebook and Google have been locked in a stare-down with news publishers and lawmakers in Australia.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac, Daisuke Wakabayashi, Damien Cave and Edmund Lee
